comment.author: 33147718@N05
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/beachcomberaustralia] I've got it! The white house is 'Cliff Towers'. From the book 'Point Piper, Past and Present': "Towards the end of the extreme north-western end of Point Piper stands a tall white house with castellated turrets, somewhat like a large lighthouse. This is 'Cliff Towers', built by Captain Samuel Charles in 1887. He was his own architect and camped in the garden to superintend the building of his home, which is indeed a landmark and a house of personality....' (p53) Which is a more diplomatic way of describing the building than Cpt Charles' obituary writer who used the word 'agressive' when referring to the building.
comment.authorname: Australian National Maritime Museum on The Commons

comment.author: 47201412@N02
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/anmm_thecommons] Brilliant! Well done. And consultation of a real physical book too! :)

comment.author: 33147718@N05
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/pellethepoet] Haha yeah I know - we went old-school on this one. Capt Samuel Charles seems like a bit of a character - come across him before?
comment.authorname: Australian National Maritime Museum on The Commons

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/anmm_thecommons] Fascinating stuff!  How about a blog article?

comment.author: 47201412@N02
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/anmm_thecommons] No, I don't think I've come across him before. I liked the reference in the obit to Captain Charles' encounter with the bushranger Frank Gardiner and the statesman William Bede Dalley playing marbles on the side of road as boys. They would have been about 13. [http://www.flickr.com/photos/beachcomberaustralia] 2007 blog about our Captain - kiamalocalhistory.wordpress.com/2007/09/01/samuel-charles... I wonder if the book was ever written?

comment.author: 33147718@N05
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/pellethepoet] [http://www.flickr.com/photos/beachcomberaustralia] Actually found the Point Piper book while researching for another blog, its all connected somehow! I like the story of Cpt Charles being the of the 'few living persons who has conversed with one of the actual witnesses of the death of Captain Cook'. Bit of a character & worth a blog! Stay tuned :) I am sure we will be spotting Cliff Towers in many of our photos from here on in.
comment.authorname: Australian National Maritime Museum on The Commons
